sn1.11:3.3: Naradeva is a term for a king. Here and at SN 9.6:4.3 it refers to the gods of the Thirty-Three, and at Thag 20.1:41.1 to Brahmā. At Cp 5:1.3 it apparently refers to the aristocrats who are “gods among men” (see Manu 11.82).
sn1.11:3.4: Tidasa (“thirty”) is a poetic abbreviation for the “thirty-three” gods.
sn1.11:5.1: The vocative form bāle suggests that a female deity is being addressed, which is certainly the case in the parallel passage at SN 9.6:5.1. The commentary says that the speaker here is also a female deity.
sn1.11:5.3: This famous verse, which occurs many times in the Suttas, was spoken by the Buddha at SN 15.20:8.2 and by Sakka, the lord of the thirty-three, at the Buddha’s passing (SN 6.15:6.2, DN 16:6.10.11. | In this context, saṅkhārā means “conditions” or “conditioned phenomena” rather than “volitional actions”, “choices”. | The unusual reading sabbasaṅkhārā (rather than vata saṅkhārā) recurs in the parallel passage at SN 9.6:5.3.
